Title: Showing $\prod\limits_{i<j} \frac{x_i-x_j}{i-j}$ is an integer
Content: Let $x_1,...,x_n$ be distinct integers. Prove that $$\prod_{i<j} \frac{x_i-x_j}{i-j}\in \mathbb Z$$ I know there is a solution using determinant of a matrix, but I can't remember it now. Any help will be appreciated.
AcceptedAnswer:
If $x_1$, $\ldots$, $x_n$ are integers, then $\prod_{1\le i<j\le n} \frac{x_i-x_j}{i-j}$ is integral because it is the determinant of the integral matrix
$$\left(x_i \choose j-1\right)_{i,j=1,\ldots,n}.$$ You can see this by starting with the formula for the determinant of the Vandermonde matrix, $$\det\left( (x_i^{j-1})_{i,j=1,\ldots,n}\right) = \prod_{1\le i<j\le n} (x_j-x_i);$$ then, divide column $j$ of the Vandermonde matrix by $(j-1)!$ to get the matrix
$$\left(\frac{x_i^{j-1}}{(j-1)!}\right)_{i,j=1,\ldots,n}$$
given by Eric Naslund above.  Its determinant equals $\prod_{1\le i<j\le n} \frac{x_j-x_i}{j-i}=\prod_{1\le i<j\le n} \frac{x_i-x_j}{i-j}$.  Finally, taking $j=n$, $n-1$, $\ldots$, $1$ in succession, add in rational multiples of columns $1$, $\ldots$, $j-1$ to column $j$ to change each $\frac{x_i^{j-1}}{(j-1)!}$ to $x_i \choose j-1$; this does not change the determinant of the matrix.
